q: What are key features of swarm intelligence?
a:
- Decentralized control: no central leader
- Parallel search: many agents work at once
- Adaptive: can adjust to changes
- Robust: works even if some agents fail

q: What are the two main sub-problems in the foraging task?
a:
- Path construction/planning: how to find paths to targets
- Path exploitation/repair: reusing and maintaining good paths

q: How do ants solve the foraging task?
a:
- Random exploration to discover paths
- Deposit pheromones on paths
- Stronger pheromones attract more ants
- Pheromones evaporate over time to remove bad paths

q: How do bees solve the foraging task?
a:
- Use Lévy flight for efficient exploration
- Use path integration to track direction and distance to nest
- Communicate food source info using a recruitment dance

q: What is a Lévy flight and why is it useful in foraging?
a:
- A search pattern combining many short moves with occasional long jumps
- Helps balance local search and global exploration

q: What is path integration (PI) in bee behavior?
a:
- A vector representing the bee's angle and distance to the nest
- Used to return directly after finding food

q: What is the purpose of the bee recruitment dance?
a:
- Done in the nest to recruit others
- Dance direction shows food direction
- Dance length indicates food quality
- Enables direct communication and autocatalytic recruitment

- An algorithm inspired by bird flocking
- Each particle adjusts its path based on:
  - Its own best position (\(\mathbf{p}_{\text{best}}\))
  - The global best position (\(\mathbf{g}_{\text{best}}\))

- Velocity and position updates:
\[
\mathbf{v}_i \leftarrow \omega \mathbf{v}_i + c_1 r_1 (\mathbf{p}_{\text{best},i} - \mathbf{x}_i) + c_2 r_2 (\mathbf{g}_{\text{best}} - \mathbf{x}_i)
\]
\[
\mathbf{x}_i \leftarrow \mathbf{x}_i + \mathbf{v}_i
\]
- Where:
  - \(\omega\): inertia weight
  - \(c_1, c_2\): acceleration coefficients
  - \(r_1, r_2\): random numbers in [0,1]

- Inspired by how ants find paths using pheromones
- Ants build paths and deposit pheromones
- More pheromones = more attractive path
- Pheromones evaporate to remove bad paths over time

q: What is swarm robotics and what are its advantages?
a:
- Applying swarm principles to robot teams
- Advantages:
  - Local communication
  - Scalability to large numbers
  - Robustness to individual failure
  - Adaptivity to new environments

q: How do fireflies synchronize in swarm robotics?
a:
- Fireflies flash in sync by adjusting to their neighbors
- Robots mimic this to synchronize actions
- Achieved through local interaction

q: How does bee-inspired foraging work in robot systems?
a:
- Robots perform Lévy flight to explore
- Use path integration to track paths
- Communicate PI vectors when they meet
- Use visual markers for food and nest

q: What are some applications of swarm robotics?
a:
- Flying robot swarms for bridge inspection
- Mobile wireless sensor networks
- Morphogenesis (forming structures)
- Exploration, patrolling, and anomaly detection
